HTMLTextAreaElement.summary: The HTMLTextAreaElement interface provides properties and methods for manipulating the layout and presentation of textarea elements.

HTMLTextAreaElementAutocomplete.summary: The autocomplete property of the interface indicates whether the value of the control can be automatically completed by the browser. It reflects the <textarea> element's autocomplete attribute.

HTMLTextAreaElementCheckValidity.summary: The checkValidity() method of the interface returns a boolean value which indicates if the element meets any constraint validation rules applied to it. If false, the method also fires an event on the element. Because there's no default browser behavior for checkValidity(), canceling this invalid event has no effect.

blockquote.para: An HTML {{htmlelement("textarea")}} element with a non-null is considered invalid, will match the CSS {{cssxref(":invalid")}} pseudo-class, and will cause checkValidity() to return false. Use the method to set the to the empty string to set the state to be valid.

remarks.para:

-form

-CSS :valid and :invalid pseudo-classes

HTMLTextAreaElementCheckValidity.returns: Returns true if the element's value has no validity problems; otherwise, returns false.

HTMLTextAreaElementDirName.summary: The dirName property of the interface is the directionality of the element. It reflects the value of the {{htmlelement("textarea")}} element's dirName attribute. This property can be retrieved or set.

remarks.para: The dirname attribute controls how the element's directionality is submitted. When included, the form control will submit with two name/value pairs: the first being the name and value of the <textarea>, and the second being the value of the dirname attribute as the name, with a value of ltr or rtl as set by the browser.

HTMLTextAreaElementMaxLength.summary: The maxLength property of the interface indicates the maximum number of characters (in {{glossary("UTF-16", "UTF-16 code units")}}) allowed to be entered for the value of the {{HTMLElement("textarea")}} element, and the maximum number of characters allowed for the value to be valid. It reflects the element's maxlength attribute. -1 means there is no limit on the length of the value.

blockquote.para: Browsers generally prevent users from entering more characters than the maxlength attribute allows. Should the length be longer, the element is considered invalid and the object's property will be true.

HTMLTextAreaElementMaxLength.value: A number representing the element's maxlength if present, or -1.

HTMLTextAreaElementMinLength.summary: The minLength property of the interface indicates the minimum number of characters (in {{glossary("UTF-16", "UTF-16 code units")}}) required for the value of the {{HTMLElement("textarea")}} element to be valid. It reflects the element's minlength attribute. -1 means there is no minimum length requirement.

blockquote.para: If the textarea has a value, and that value has fewer characters than the minlength attribute requires, the element is considered invalid and the object's property will be true.

HTMLTextAreaElementMinLength.value: A number representing the element's minlength if present or -1.

HTMLTextAreaElementName.summary: The name property of the interface indicates the name of the {{HTMLElement("textarea")}} element. It reflects the element's name attribute.
HTMLTextAreaElementName.value: A string representing the element's name.

HTMLTextAreaElementSelectionchange.summary:
The selectionchange event of the Selection API is fired when the text selection within a textarea element is changed.
This includes both changes in the selected range of characters, or if the caret moves.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable.
The event is usually processed by adding an event listener on the {{HTMLElement("textarea")}}, and in the handler function read by the selectionStart, selectionEnd and selectionDirection properties.

It is also possible to add a listener on the global onselectionchange event handler, and within the handler function use to get the . However this is not very useful for getting changes to text selections.

HTMLTextAreaElementSelectionDirection.summary: The selectionDirection property of the interface specifies the current direction of the selection. The possible values are "forward", "backward", and "none". The forward value indicates the selection was performed in the start-to-end direction of the current locale, with backward indicating the opposite direction. The none value occurs if the direction is unknown. It can be used to both retrieve and change the direction of the <textarea>s selected text.

remarks.para: Setting the selectionDirection to a new value fires the and events.

HTMLTextAreaElementSelectionEnd.summary: The selectionEnd property of the interface specifies the end position of the current text selection in a {{HTMLElement("textarea")}} element. It is a number representing the last index of the selected text. It can be used to both retrieve and set the index of the end of a <textarea>s selected text.

remarks.para: When nothing is selected, the value of both the and selectionEnd is the position of the cursor (caret) inside the <textarea> element.

Setting selectionEnd to a value less than the current value of updates both the selectionEnd and selectionStart properties to that value. If both value are less than 0, both properties are set to the property value.
The property value can be retrieved and set without the <textarea> having focus, but the element does need to have focus for the {{cssxref("::selection")}} pseudo-element to match the selected text.
Setting the selectionEnd to a new value fires the and events.

HTMLTextAreaElementSetRangeText.summary:
The setRangeText() method of the interface replaces a
range of text in a textarea element with new text passed as the argument.

remarks.para: Additional optional parameters include the start of the section of text to change, the end of the section, and a keyword defining what part of the <textarea> should be selected after the text is updated. If the startSelection and endSelection arguments are not provided, the range is assumed to be the selection.

The final argument determines how the selection will be set after the text has been replaced. The possible values are "select", which selects the newly inserted text, "start", which moves the selection to just before the inserted text, "end", which moves the selection to just after the inserted text, or the default, "preserve", which tries to preserve the selection.
In addition, the and events are fired.

The direction indicates the in which selection should be considered to have occurred; for example, that the selection was set by the user clicking and dragging from the end of the selected text toward the beginning. In addition, the and events are fired.
